questions.text: In a forensic medicine case review session, a PG resident is discussing the techniques used for age determination in cases involving unidentified remains. A key focus is on the role of ossification centers in estimating developmental stages, particularly in fetal and infant remains. The PG presents a scenario where the remains of a fetus was found, and the determination of the developmental stage is crucial for the ongoing investigation. Based on the standard timeline for the appearance of ossification centers, at what stage of development do the earliest centers of ossification typically appear?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 5-6 weeks

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The earliest centers of ossification are typically visible by 5-6 weeks in utero , marking a significant milestone in embryonic development . The clavicle is the first bone to ossify in the body from two membranous primary ossification centers during the 5–6 th postovulatory week . A secondary center forms in the sternal end between 15–17 years and fuses by 20–22 years . In majority of the bones, primary centers of ossification appear between 7 th and 12 th weeks of intrauterine life . 52 By the age of 11–12 th week of IUL , there are 806 centers of ossification.

questions.text: A forensic team investigates a scene where a 45-year-old woman was found deceased under mysterious circumstances. The primary task is to establish the foundation for a potential criminal investigation. In this context, the concept of "corpus delicti" is crucial. What does "corpus delicti" specifically refer to in forensic pathology and legal medicine?
questions.correct_answer: A. Proof of occurrence of crime
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Proof of occurrence of crime

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Corpus delicti (delicti=fault; offence) (the body of offence; the essence of crime)
  • • Corpus delicti
  • • (the body of offence; the essence of crime)
  • • The facts of any criminal offence , e.g., murder . Ex - The corpus delicti of murder is the fact that a person died from unlawful violence . It includes the body of the victim and other facts which are conclusive of death by foul play, such as a bullet or a broken knife-blade found in the body and responsible for death. Clothing’s showing marks of the weapon, and drawings and photographs of the deceased showing fatal injuries are also included in this term. The main part of corpus delicti is the establishment of identity of the dead body, and infliction of violence in a particular way, at a particular time and place , by the person or persons charged with the crime . The identification of a dead body and proof of corpus delicti is important before a sentence is passed in murder trials , as unclaimed , decomposed bodies , or portions of a dead body , or bones are sometimes produced to support false charges . However, a conviction for an offence does not necessarily depend upon the corpus delicti , if there are eyewitnesses or strong corroborative evidence .
  • • The facts of any criminal offence , e.g., murder . Ex - The corpus delicti of murder is the fact that a person died from unlawful violence . It includes the body of the victim and other facts which are conclusive of death by foul play, such as a bullet or a broken knife-blade found in the body and responsible for death. Clothing’s showing marks of the weapon, and drawings and photographs of the deceased showing fatal injuries are also included in this term.

questions.text: During a forensic anthropology class, PG Residents are presented with an intriguing challenge by their professor. They are shown a well-preserved sternum recovered from an archaeological site. The Professor asks the residents to identify the rule that describes the body of the sternum as typically being longer and more than twice the length of the manubrium. This rule is essential in the anthropological evaluation of skeletal remains. Which rule is the Professor referring to?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hyrtl’s rule

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option A: Puppe’s rule - lt can determine the sequence of shots when several bullets have struck the cranium . This rule is applicable to any multiple blunt force , causing skull fractures . This rule has been developed by Madea in relation to bullet injuries . The test depends on the observations of the fracture lines either when they intersect each other, or when they intersect a cratered lesion , so that one can determine which crack or defect must have been formed first.

questions.text: During a training session on forensic odontology, a group of medical residents is introduced to various methods used for age estimation in children. The instructor presents a case study where the age of a child was determined through an analysis of the child's teeth, focusing on a specific method that utilizes the height and weight of teeth. questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Stack's method.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B: Boyde's method : This method, applicable mainly to estimate age of dead infants, is based on counting the number of cross striations in the enamel of teeth (incremental lines) from neonatal line onwards.

  • • applicable mainly to estimate age of dead infants,
  • • counting the number of cross striations in the enamel of teeth
  • • Ameloblasts produce enamel at a rate of 4 U/ day . The new enamel formed each day appears as distinct line called incremental line in histology sections. The darkest incremental line is formed at birth due to stress of being born . This is called neonatal line. Counting the incremental lines in enamel outside the neonatal line can reveal the post-natal age. Counting lines prior to neonatal line will give prenatal age.
  • • Ameloblasts produce enamel at a rate of 4 U/ day

Is for estimation of age after 25 years. Useful only while examining dead body or skeletal remains, as teeth need to be extracted for examination.
  • • Option C:
  • • Gustafson's method
  • • Age estimation consists of microscopic examination of longitudinal section of central part of the tooth
  • • changes in teeth
  • • wear and tear with advancing age
  • • Option D: Pearson's method - Pearson’s regression formula is used determine the stature based on long bones (first reported this in 1899). When whole skeleton is not available, but one or the other long bones are available, then regression equations are used.

  • • Stature = 81.306 + 1.88 × F (length of femur in males)

questions.text: A forensic expert is evaluating evidence at a crime scene. Among the collected items, strands of hair are found, which could be pivotal in linking a suspect to the scene. To determine their origin, the analyst must compare their microscopic characteristics to known human and animal hair attributes. Upon microscopic examination of hair strands found at a crime scene, which feature would most likely determine if the hair is of human or animal origin?

options.label: A
options.text: If the hair displays a continuous medulla, it is indicative of human origin.

options.label: B
options.text: A hair with pigment granules distributed toward the cuticle rather than the medulla suggests animal origin.

options.label: C
options.text: The presence of a root that is brush-like in appearance would suggest the hair is of animal origin.

options.label: D
options.text: Hair with a very narrow or absent medulla is typically characteristic of animal hair.

questions.correct_answer: C. The presence of a root that is brush-like in appearance would suggest the hair is of animal origin.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The presence of a root that is brush-like in appearance would suggest the hair is of animal origin.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Incorrect . A continuous medulla is more commonly associated with animal hair ; human hair may have a fragmented or absent medulla.
  • • Option A:
  • • Incorrect
  • • continuous medulla is more commonly associated with animal hair
  • • Option B: Incorrect . Pigment granules near the cuticle are not a primary distinguishing feature between human and animal hair.
  • • Option B:
  • • Incorrect
  • • Pigment granules near the cuticle are not a primary distinguishing feature
  • • Option D: Incorrect , narrow, or absent medulla is characteristic of Human Hair .
  • • Option D:
  • • Incorrect
  • • absent medulla is characteristic of Human Hair

The hair features, including shaft diameter, root shape, and medullary index , differ significantly between humans and animals.
